column1: Context-Aware Event Recommendation in Event-based Social Networks
The Web has grown into one of the most important channels to communicate social events nowadays. However
column2: the sheer volume of events available in event-based social networks (EBSNs) often undermines the users' ability to choose the events that best fit their interests. Recommender systems appear as a natural solution for this problem

column5: the event recommendation problem is intrinsically cold-start. Indeed
column6: events published in EBSNs are typically short-lived and
column9: having little or no trace of historical attendance. To overcome this limitation
column10: we propose to exploit several contextual signals available from EBSNs. In particular
column11: besides content-based signals based on the events' description and collaborative signals derived from users' RSVPs
column12: we exploit social signals based on group memberships
column13: location signals based on the users' geographical preferences
column14: and temporal signals derived from the users' time preferences. Moreover
column15: we combine the proposed signals for learning to rank events for personalized recommendation. Thorough experiments using a large crawl of Meetup.com demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed contextual learning approach in contrast to state-of-the-art event recommenders from the literature.
